normalised: Basically, rental yield is the annual rental income you get from a property, expressed as a percentage of its value. Simple formula: (Annual Rent divided by Property Value) asterisk one hundred.

unnormalised: Basically, rental yield is the annual rental income you get from a property, expressed as a percentage of its value. Simple formula: (Annual Rent / Property Value) * 100.
normalised: So, if you buy a one B H K in Andheri for rupee eighty lakhs and rent it out for rupee twenty thousand a month, your annual rent is rupee two point four lakhs. Yield equals (two point four L divided by eighty L) asterisk one hundred equals three percent.

unnormalised: So, if you buy a 1 BHK in Andheri for Rs. 80 Lakhs and rent it out for Rs. 20,000 a month, your annual rent is Rs. 2.4 Lakhs. Yield = (2.4L/80L) * 100 = 3%.
normalised: Now, "good" depends. In Mumbai, you’re generally looking at two to four percent. Anything above four percent and Doctor Shah might tell you to double-check the paperwork! Areas further out like Panvel might offer higher yields (maybe five to six percent), but you need to factor in commute to your office (if you’re living elsewhere) and infrastructure.

normalised: Essentially, do your homework! Talk to a local broker like Ramesh bhai, who’s been selling property in Dadar for twenty years, before making any decisions. Remember, a higher yield doesn't always mean a better investment. A property with poor maintenance or located in a dodgy area will likely have higher vacancy rates, eating into your profits. Plus, that four hundred square foot flat might become more expensive to maintain over time! Good luck, and happy investing!
